ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Close reading of key works by Plato and Aristotle, got to examine fundamental questions of justice
I learned about the themes and rhetorical techniques used in Plato's Apology and Republic and in Aristotle's Politics.

This course offered an in-depth understanding of Aristotle and Plato's most prominent political works. It would be a strong foundation for any student interested in taking future philosophy or political theory courses because of the emphasis on close reading and direct engagement with primary source texts.
I learned a lot about Aristotle and Socrates and the context in which they philosophized. I also learned about their conceptions of a city and of government.
Critical thinking, comparative thought, textual interpretation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a great opportunity to study works of ancient political philosophy in depth. Professor Wilford used a good balance of lecture about historical context and tradition and class discussion. There were one or two classes where she emailed questions in advance to guide the readings and I think that would be really to have for all the readings.
Strengths: deep dive and close looking into the two philosophers. Weaknesses: material a little hard to engage with, same class structure every time.

Strengths
- The course syllabus was extremely well crafted, clear, and comprehensive, 
- Course assignments were fair and clear. 
- There was a strong mix between lecturing from Professor Wilford and classroom discussion. 
- Professor Wilford habitually made connections between and encouraged students to make connections between contemporary American politics and the politics of ancient Athens, which made the course extremely relevant.

Weaknesses
-There were no substantial weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the course ran about the same way virtually that it would have in person.
Zoom seminars are always a bit rough! It was OK otherwise.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, everyone should read and study Plato's Apology!
Yes. The course would be great either as an initial introduction to Plato and Aristotle or for students who have already covered their works to analyze them more in-depth.
I would if they want to know about Socrates and Aristotle.

Absolutely! This course dives more deeply into close readings of Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle than comprehensive survey courses have time to do. Any student who wants a foundation in ancient Greek political thought should take this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
